label: Letter 2 from Sidney Jennings Legendre, August 6, 1943
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, advising her to sell Medway Plantation if she can, describing the apartment house he and Morris purchased in Hawaii, and discussing the possibility of them living in Hawaii after the war. Sidney continues in his letter to tell her of a friend from New Orleans coming to visit and their social activities. [Copy]

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
Copy to American
Embassy
31
August 6, 1943
Dear Gertie,
In allt he world that is the fastest letter you wrote
me that I have ever received. You mailed it at 5PM August the
3rd and I received it at two oclock August 6th. That means it
really only took the third fourth and fifth to get here, the
rest of the time it stayed in p[o]st offices. Just three days
to go six thousand miles, incredible. I received a letter from
you yesterday dated July 31, written from Severn, Horse Hollow
Road, Polly's house. I read Morris passages from them both and
we roared with laughter at the descriptions fo the old women with
their bare arms jangling with bracelets and the prop[o]sed sale of
Boone Hall. If you can c tch a sucker for Medway and the two
thousand five hundred acres for one hundred and fifty thousand I
would do it. Keep Spring grove and pine grove for o r own shootin
and hunting, besides a little land to grow carrots in.
You could put up a tiny house at spring grove for ten thousand
after the war, would be on a paved road, and not have the expense
of keeping up an enormous place as yo would only go there for the
shoot ng as your real house would be in a much better place.
I cannot tell you where to live out here as I am unable
to leave the island on leave, there is no leave. I was sent away
on the ship for four days but that was business. Morris is leaving
Monday on a cruise. As a result I ill not be able to get that
other bathing suit that you want for some time . Two reasons are
behind this. One there are not any in town. You will remember 
that youasked me for one in November. I use to ring the stores
up abo t once a week and ask if they had any. Always the answer
was no. Tina ly one d y The East I[N]dia Shop or something
like that saidthey had a few and I rushed into town and pushed
my way through a mass of milling women to snatch those two out
for you. As soon as some more come to town I will descend and
capture a few. The other reason why it is so difficult to get
any is that I cannot pull out of the office when I want to.
I would have to get the captains permission to leave, and though
I can do this the day the suits are there[,]I cannot do it everyday
and go shopping to try and find them. However I will certainly
keep my eyes and ears open and will send you a couple as soon
as I can.
C[a]n you imagine that old Grodon Dougl_as ma ried
again. I thought I was so old that you would throw me out of the
hose as useless but when I hear that such an old dodderer as that
marries gain I know for certain that marriage must be based on
compan onship, there could be nothing else there. You say that
you hope that I could walk into the room and the same [S]idney
you once knew. That is impossible. I am now a hard , furrowed
face man. A creat re of strnage and horrible moods. Sardonic
nd untrustworthy, but I must admit that a long eared fat
spaniel still breaks me down.
[End Page 1]
The conrete house that I wrote you about was the same
house that I first described to you as dripping with
bouganville, high up on the hi[L]l overl[o]oking the sea with
the be ches on either side curxxving towxards the Royal
and cocox head. You can see what a difference a little discript
ion makes. Many times I have wonered what you wi l l think of
the island after you have seen it with only the descriptions
of my letters to go on from the day we were hexre together.
I will admit that t times I have drawn a rather long bow to
make it at[T]ractive, but all in all it is the most attractive pla
ce that I have been in in the last eleven months. Maybe
you wont be able to buy a place after the war[,]but maybe you
will , Who can [s]ee intothe future. We will have time to find x
placed when I have seen nothing else for a year, seen only
Navy life and Navy peoplex. Maybe the people on the island are
terrible. Perhaps it is a wild drinking likfe or a sour
old maids paradise. I have seen nothing but the outrigger club
and the Royal Hawaiian movies.
We had great fun this even ng. A boy from New Orleans
who we had not seen for years rang up and came over the otherx
night. We asked him to p;ay tennis and have dinner with us,
We met him on the tennis court of the Royal t[h]is afternoon
and had great fun playing. When I last saw him he was
sixteen with a round sweet face and the most perfect manners you
have ever seen. He is now a commander in the Navy, captain of
a submarine and has done the most wonderful job, and has
been decorated ever so many times. His face is le[a]n and hard
but he is just as nice as ever. Just returned from a cruise on
which his ship had done wonders and is now resting with his
crew before taking off again. I thought of the time when yo and
I were here and we had a room and danced in the ballroom do wnst
airs. However I could not remember t e otel very weill or wher
our room was. His room us e to cost one hundred do_llars
a day, it has an enormous balcony looking over the sea and the
dance floor. It cost him one dollar a day with his meals
incl ded. From there we went to the Outrigger for
dinner with three other submarine o[f]ficers and all talked.
They were fascinating, what lives they live. Always being
b[e]pth bombed[,]never knowing when they will see the sun again.
r[e]ally men of iron. After dinner we went back to the outrigger
and saw the movies and then ho[m] to write to you. One f the
bo s from the office is staying with us tonight and I have left
him outside in the living room where he will sleep on a sofa.
Morris of course is in his ro m rea ing with his fat
stomach going up and down very slowly as he smokes a big black
cigar. He loves cigars b t like your father lets them go out
all the time. Everytime he relights it I think a gas house or
a garbage heap has been moved into the ap[a]rtmkent.
That elephone bill certainly sounded like the
[End Page 2]
National debt, but it was worth it and great fun to talk again.
That reminds me you mentioned in our conversation about houses
and the people that are buying them. There is quite a furor
our here because all the Japs are buying the hose for casex, and
the the saying on the islandis that the Japs will have won Hawaii
no matter who wins the war. I think it is right because apparently
when the Japs and orientals move into a neighborhood the nice
people move out just l[i]ke when the jews move in . That is why
it is so difficult now to know where to buy as a[L]l the old neigh-
borhoods are being ivaded and conquered.
How is it that you were at the island and at the river club
and did not beat the tennis ball back and forth. You don't mean 
to say that you have slipped and become a weakling, a women that
does not want to tire all the men out. I cannot believe it.
Surely you kust have been playing something some where.
I may not be ble to write you next week as often as I
will have to take over Morrises work, and he really has some work,
and that is no fooling. I bet I will be plowed under. The
cpatain calls on him about every five minutes besides all the
other officers. He shou[l]d be a captain because he does the
best j[o]b you have seen. The Navy's idea of promotion is nuts.
Everyone goes up together bad or good. Here th ey have a man
that should be a the head of an entire bureau. Brains tack,
everything ti takes and they have him a lieutenant, his position
a sort of mail clerk, when acutally he does everything.
So ong nuts I have not the faintest idea where you will
receive this but it carries my love to the place tha t you do .
Sidney J Legendre
[End Page 3]
